metadata.title: How to Effortlessly Create, Publish, and Even Share Cloud Hosted-Jupyter Notebooks with Saturn Cloud | by Anne Bonner | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: How to Effortlessly Create, Publish, and Even Share Cloud Hosted-Jupyter Notebooks with Saturn Cloud
metadata.description: The data science environment is changing. Whether you’re an experienced practitioner or still in school, being able to share your work is a necessity. With Saturn Cloud, that process is simple!

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: You can find the details here
Head over here and take a look for yourself

all_paragraphs: It’s hard not to love Saturn Cloud.
I recently started using a hosted Jupyter service called Saturn Cloud, and it’s amazing.

With Saturn Cloud, it’s unbelievably easy to run cloud-hosted Jupyter Notebooks. You click a few buttons and you’re completely set up. You’re ready to create, run, publish, and even share Jupyter Notebooks. You can even collaborate with other people! It might be the easiest way out there for data scientists to use cloud-based computing for their Jupyter Notebooks. It’s the only way I’ve found that allows you to immediately (and painlessly!) publish and share your notebooks with the world.
If you want to see exactly how quick and painless it is to get set up with Saturn Cloud and share your notebooks, scroll down to “Setting up Saturn Cloud.”

The data science environment is changing. Whether you’re an experienced professional or still in school, sharing your work gets more important every day. Being able to publish and collaborate on your notebooks with almost no effort is amazing!

There really isn’t another simple way to share notebooks that your team can collaborate on. (At least not without hiring someone to set it up...) If you’re just out of school, this is a big hurdle! It’s also a problem for companies who already have expensive data scientists on the payroll that need to be focusing on the data, and not trying to find some kind of workaround. With Saturn Cloud, it’s ridiculously simple.

Jupyter Notebooks are one of the best (free!) tools available to help you gain the skills you need to be effective in a ton of data-related fields. They’re the ideal tool for data science, machine learning, deep learning, artificial intelligence, and more. They can hold not just code, but rich text elements like images, figures, links, and way more. This makes them a perfect place to bring together an analysis, your results, and a description of what’s going on.
There are also about a million ways to customize your Jupyter Notebook and make it amazing…

If you aren’t familiar with Jupyter Notebooks, working with them is incredibly simple once you know what you’re doing. There can be a few hiccups getting started with Anaconda and Jupyter Notebooks, but they’re a breeze to use once you’re all set up, and they're a lot of fun to customize.
If you’re having trouble getting set up, you might want to check out this article:

As easy as they are to work with, they’re often difficult to get up and running with a cloud-hosted service. There are a ton of people out there who have gotten completely stuck just trying to get their notebooks running with a cloud provider.
That’s where Saturn Cloud comes in!
If you can figure out how to order something on Amazon, you can get set up on Saturn Cloud.
First and foremost, Saturn Cloud is led by a couple of pretty incredible people:
(You can find that information right here.)
I’ve been lucky enough to get to spend a little time talking with them and can tell you that these are some pretty incredible human beings.

Full disclosure: The reason I’ve had a chance to talk with them is because I’ve done a little bit of work for Saturn Cloud (and have gotten paid by them). On the other hand, that means that I’ve gotten to know what a great team of people they are and I’ve had a chance to play around with what they have to offer!

There are a few services that offer cloud-hosted Jupyter Notebooks, like Google Cloud, and Amazon SageMaker. These are great options! But they aren’t always that simple to work with. There have been a lot of articles written about getting your Jupyter Notebooks to run in Azure, Google Cloud, and SageMaker. When you read the articles, you can see that some platforms are definitely easier than others. There are usually a lot of steps involved if you want to get things right.
Setting up Saturn Cloud, on the other hand, is practically effortless.
Saturn Cloud is simple, free, available to everyone, and completely effortless.
Saturn Cloud couldn’t be simpler to set up. You just click a few buttons to get everything working. It takes about two minutes.
If you can figure out how to order something on Amazon, you can get set up on Saturn Cloud.

You can find the official documentation here, but all you need to do is sign up and you’ll be dropped in your dashboard. You’ll name your Jupyter, choose how much disk space you need, how much ram/CPU/GPU you want and hit “Create.”
You’ll probably be up and running in less than a minute!
If you’re someone who forgets to hit the stop button when you’re done, make sure you set your auto shutoff so that you can avoid unnecessary charges!

Now you’ll see a link to your Jupyter Notebook and a link to your Jupyter Lab. Just click on the link to your Jupyter Notebook if you want to go directly to a notebook and get started. You’ll see a play button that starts your Jupyter, a stop button that stops it running, an edit button for modifying your server, and a trash icon that will delete your Jupyter.
You can even customize your Python and Linux environments if you want. Take a look at the advanced options if you want to create new environments within your home directory.
Click “Go to Jupyter Notebook” and build something incredible!
If you want to share your notebook, it’s unbelievably simple. You can find the details here. All you need to do is open a terminal right in your Jupyter lab.
Run this simple line of code, replacing “notebooks” with the name of your folder or notebook:

Reload the “How to Publish” page and you’ll see the name of your published notebooks on your screen. Click on your notebook’s name to configure how it gets published. You might want to change the title or add a description. You definitely want to decide if the notebooks are secret and whether you want to let others anonymously execute your notebook. (Compute charges from those executions would be billed to your account.) Everything is incredibly clear, so don’t worry about surprises!
Now you have a published notebook that looks great!
Head over here and take a look for yourself!

With Saturn Cloud, you have all of the advantages of Jupyter Notebooks, unbelievable speed, and you can even publish and share your work. If you’re tired of the drawbacks of the free options and you want to be able to start right now and focus on your data without jumping through a bunch of hoops, take a look at Saturn Cloud.
Thanks for reading! As always, if you do anything amazing with this information, let everybody know about it in the comments below or reach out any time on LinkedIn @annebonnerdata.
